channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukrainians Brace for a Cold Winter Amid Russian Conflict
item.description: In cities and towns battered by the war, residents worry about how to heat their homes as temperatures drop. But even in places spared from the worst of the fighting, Russian strikes on infrastructure have raised new fears.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Brendan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times

item.title: As War Rages, a Ukrainian Family in Michigan Holds On to Home
item.description: Amber Galkin and her children find themselves navigating complicated connections with their homeland as they embrace a new national identity.
item.dc:creator: Peter Kujawinski and Erin Kirkland for The New York Times

item.title: Steve Bannon Sentenced to 4 Months in Prison for Contempt of Congress
item.description: Stephen Bannon was found guilty of two counts of contempt of Congress this summer for defying a subpoena from the House Jan. 6 committee.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:description: Stephen K. Bannon has used his daily internet radio show to skewer the government for prosecuting him.

item.title: Could Boris Johnson Make a Comeback as U.K. Prime Minister?
item.description: A comeback by Mr. Johnson is viewed as a very real possibility, delighting some Conservative Party lawmakers and repelling others.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler

item.title: Boris Johnson and Rishi Sunak Among Top Contenders to Replace UK Prime Minister
item.description: Former Prime Minister Boris Johnson and the man who helped oust him from his job, the former Finance Minister Rishi Sunak, are seen as two of the top contenders within the governing Conservative Party.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: The door to 10 Downing Street in London, the prime minister’s office and residence.

item.title: Who Will the Next U.K. Prime Minister Be and How Will They Be Chosen?
item.description: The process, which does not include the general public, will be swift, with plans to have a result by next week.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Britain could have a new prime minister as soon as Monday.

item.title: Federal Budget Deficit Fell to $1.4 Trillion as Pandemic Spending Eased
item.description: The gap between what the government borrows and what it spends narrowed amid less spending and higher tax receipts.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: President Biden said on Friday that the federal budget deficit fell to $1.4 trillion.

item.title: As Inflation Stalks Europe, Leaders Shudder
item.description: The downfall of Britain’s prime minister served as a warning to all of the political peril that awaits those who fail to address the erosion of living standards, no matter the cause.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: A market in Milan. The incoming government of Giorgia Meloni will have to struggle with how to cushion inflation’s blow in Italy without inflating already bloated deficits.

item.title: Life Was Built Around Snow. What Happens When It Vanishes?
item.description: The melting of the snowpack in the high Cascades has long been a predictable source of sustenance in the Pacific Northwest. But the old patterns are changing.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Fremson and Kirk Johnson
item.media:description: The borderlands at their feet, straddling Oregon and Washington, nurture farms and ranches, fruit-growing and fishing. The powerful winds that blow up the Columbia River attract windsurfers from around the world.

item.title: She’s Inheriting Millions of Euros. She Wants Her Wealth Taxed Away.
item.description: Marlene Engelhorn, 30, heir to a fortune, isn’t interested in philanthropy, believing it only perpetuates existing power dynamics. She’s calling for structural change to how the ultrarich are taxed.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy
item.media:credit: Mashid Mohadjerin for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The dream scenario is I get taxed,” said Ms. Engelhorn, the co-founder of a group called Tax Me Now.

item.title: Airlines Cash In as Flexible Work Changes Travel Patterns
item.description: Untethered from desks, passengers are flying more often and in different ways. Carriers expect the new habits to endure, despite economic uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:credit: Gabby Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Remote work and hybrid work have allowed Americans to travel more and combine personal and professional trips.

item.title: A Coming-Out Party for Generative A.I., Silicon Valley’s New Craze
item.description: A celebration for Stability AI, the start-up behind the controversial Stable Diffusion image generator, represents the arrival of a new A.I. boom.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emad Mostaque, the founder and chief executive of the start-up Stability AI.

item.title: Taylor Swift Releases ‘Midnights,’ Her 10th Studio Album
item.description: The singer-songwriter’s 10th studio album is a return to the pop pipeline, with production from her longtime collaborator Jack Antonoff.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:description: Taylor Swift announced the 13-track “Midnights” two months ago, calling it “the story of 13 sleepless nights scattered throughout my life.”

item.title: Democrats Should Be Freaking Out a Little About South Texas
item.description: In this deep-blue area of a red state, the Republican Party is focusing on local races in a quest to transform the political landscape.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Cottle
item.media:credit: Verónica G. Cárdenas for The New York Times

item.title: Can Tim Ryan Pull Off the Biggest Upset of the Midterms in Ohio?
item.description: The Democrats are doing almost exactly what he said they should to save their political fortunes in the Midwest. But is it enough to win Ohio?
item.dc:creator: Alec MacGillis
item.media:credit: Megan Jelinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tim Ryan, the Democratic Senate nominee in Ohio, in Columbus this month. As manufacturing has declined in the state, so have Democratic fortunes.

item.title: Why Republicans Are Surging
item.description: The Democrats have serious holes in their political strategy.
item.dc:creator: David Brooks
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times

item.title: What if We Let Majoritarian Democracy Take Root?
item.description: Majority rule is not perfect but rule by a narrow, reactionary minority is far worse.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie

item.title: Liz Truss and the Ruination of Britain
item.description: The Conservative Party has brought chaos to the country.
item.dc:creator: Peter Oborne

item.title: Finally, a Great Movie About Cancel Culture
item.description: Why we need films like “Tár.”
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; photograph by Focus Features

item.title: Notes on the Condition of Liberalism
item.description: The prospects for our present order’s renewal — or collapse.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat

item.title: Will Gas Prices Doom Democracy?
item.description: Their political salience is ludicrous, and terrifying.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman

item.title: Liz Truss’s Downfall
item.description: Liz Truss is inflation’s latest political victim, and probably not its last.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez

item.title: The Rapid Downfall of Liz Truss
item.description: Ms. Truss is the shortest-serving prime minister in British history. How did she get here?
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Michael Simon Johnson, Rachelle Bonja, Will Reid, Chris Wood, Sydney Harper, Anita Badejo and Marion Lozano
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss delivered her resignation statement outside 10 Downing Street on Thursday in London.

item.title: Generative A.I. Is Here. Who Should Control It?
item.description: Emad Mostaque, the founder of Stability AI, says his Stable Diffusion image generator is the key to unlocking creativity. His critics say it’s a potential threat.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Paula Szuchman, Corey Schreppel, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Elisheba Ittoop

item.title: This Minnesota Race Will Show the Potency of Crime vs. Abortion
item.description: Keith Ellison, the state’s progressive attorney general, faces a Republican challenger who is looking to harness public unease since George Floyd’s murder.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: Glen Stubbe/Star Tribune, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Attorney General Keith Ellison of Minnesota, right, and his Republican challenger, Jim Schultz, before a debate in St. Paul.

item.title: Imran Khan, Pakistan’s Ex-Leader, Is Barred From Office
item.description: The decision by Pakistan’s election commission is a major escalation of the showdown between the ruling establishment and Mr. Khan, and it raises the specter of unrest.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan in September outside a court in Islamabad.

item.title: Why Thanksgiving Turkeys Will Cost More This Year
item.description: With avian flu, inflation and supply-chain challenges, this could be a rough year for getting just the bird you want.
item.dc:creator: Kim Severson
item.media:credit: Kaiti Sullivan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Broad-breasted white turkeys live on 20 acres designated for them at Gunthorp Farms in LaGrange, Ind.

item.title: ‘Millionaires Versus Billionaires’: The Fight Over a Hamptons Airport
item.description: Neighbors have long complained of the noise, but a judge ruled that a plan to privatize the municipal airport to reduce air traffic was improper.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: The advent of loud, ride-share style helicopters roughly 10 years ago escalated the local battle over the East Hampton Municipal Airport.

item.title: As Britain’s Economy Stumbles, One Sector Is Booming: Whisky
item.description: Scotch whisky exports have soared this year. The weak British pound could spur even more demand for single malt scotch.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Kieran Dodds

item.title: Melatonin for Sleep: How the Aid Works
item.description: The “vampire hormone” can act like a dose of sunset, tricking your body into feeling like it’s time to sleep.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: The Best Exercises to Prevent Lower Back Pain
item.description: Back pain is common and complicated. But altering your workout to build control and stability can help prevent it.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Cole Barash for The New York Times

item.title: How A.D.H.D. Can Affect Your Relationships
item.description: The symptoms of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder can push couples to their breaking point, but there is hope for those willing to seek help.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: How Fermented Foods May Alter Your Microbiome and Improve Your Health
item.description: Foods like yogurt, kimchi, sauerkraut and kombucha increased the diversity of gut microbes and led to lower levels of inflammation.
item.dc:creator: Anahad O’Connor
item.media:credit: Andrew Scrivani for The New York Times

item.title: Do Antidepressants Work for Severe PMS?
item.description: Premenstrual dysphoric disorder, or PMDD, is an extreme and often debilitating form of PMS that can be tricky to manage. Here’s what treatments work.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Rabkin Peachman
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Review: In ‘Topdog/Underdog,’ Staying Alive Is the Ultimate Hustle
item.description: A latter-day Lincoln and Booth try to survive the American dream in a hilarious, harrowing and superbly acted Broadway revival of the Suzan-Lori Parks play.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Green
item.media:description: Yahya Abdul-Mateen II, left, as Booth, and Corey Hawkins as Lincoln in the Pulitzer Prize-winning play “Topdog/Underdog” at the Golden Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
